question: What does commoning with tech mean to you?
How ready are you to give up individualism (for the sake of commons, community)?
How important is knowing each other for a commonist situation?
Can we think algorithms as common? Is there an algorithmic commons?
Why do you think are utopias always communist/commonist and why does this not work in reality?
comments: this could be connected with question 4

question: Is technology based on reason or on rhetoric?
Who decides what is of value to whom?

How good or bad it is when capitalism swallows anarchic / commonist ideas? for example the horizontalization of companies structure. Or how do you see it: are we feeding justice to capitalism, or is capitalism using this to its own gain?
What does money ruin? What benefits could money-less economy bring?
What is the biggest difference between commoning and the sharing economy?

If a community turned completely towards circular economy - so that members do not have to work outside of the tasks they contribute to community life - what media could you envision to facilitate that?
How are decentralization and technology related to each other?
Is a good society a predictable society?
Is surveillance always bad?
How can we build up trust in a community?
What is an ideal (good) scale for a commoning community - household / region / global?
How can infrastructure support stuartship and care?
When is the time to automate and when is the time to re/negotiate?
How can an algorithm be fairer than those who design it?
Who do you trust more: people or algorithms? Or even more broader: people or technology?
comments: originally, this question was why do we trust people more than algorithms - I think it's more interesting this way

question: What technology can you envision to account for agency of non-human actants in commoning situations?
Can the idea of "packet switching" in networking be applied to a commoning situation such as "warm water switching", "dinner switching" or "task switching"?

Typical capitalist business claims that in order to provide an optimal quality of a service, centralization is necessary (think At&T for telecommunications or Holywood for cinema). What commoning tech would we need so that alternative models of services and production could flourish?
Data mining versus simulation for commoning?
What techniques of (quickly) disclosing your identity can you think of?
comments: here i think of authenticity and authentication, bitcoin style trust etc

question: How can a community communicate its values or expectations?
How could future technologies foster commoning?
What technologies and media facilitate commoning of resources?
Do you think decentralization is a phantasm?
comments: to me this feels to obvious of a blockchain question

question: How can commoning inspire design of new systems?
